newsitem.title: FINLAND: Singer&Friedlander unit buys Finnish broker.
newsitem.headline: Singer&Friedlander unit buys Finnish broker.

text.p: The brokerage, asset management and mutual fund operations of Carnegie Finland will merge with local rival Pankkiiriliike Erik Selin Ab Bankirfirma by June 15, the companies said in a joint statement on Friday.
Carnegie is 55-percent owned by British investment bank and fund management group Singer&Friedlander and 45-percent by Carnegie staff.

The merger will take place through a purchase by Carnegie of Erik Selin's business operations including the mutual funds arm Erik Selin Rahasto Oy, they said, adding the deal did not cover other operations of the Selin Finance group.
The price of the deal was not given.
The two companies' combined market share in brokering is about 10 percent. Their asset management operations and mutual funds look after total capital worth over two billion markka.
The new entity would have a staff of just over 50 people.
Matti Kinnunen, chairman of the board of Carnegie Securities Finland, said in the statement that the merger aimed to turn Carnegie into a leading investment services company independent of banks.
By joining forces with Selin, Carnegie would reach a similar leading position in Finland as it already has in other Nordic countries, he said.
